Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A Smartphone-Based Handheld Sensor for Accurate and Quantitative Detection of Toxic Ion Contaminants in Environmental Water
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is a portable, low-cost plug and play mobile internet integrated sensor product catering to the needs of water quality monitoring market, a global market with a compounded annual growth rate of 4-6%. The water testing equipment market is divided into low-end, low-cost on-field test equipment (such as nitrate strip) that gives qualitative information about the analytes, and high-end testing devices used in labs (such as mass spectrometer) providing accurate quantitative information. If successful, this sensor technology will bridge the gap by providing low-cost, sensitive, accurate tools for quantitative measurement of analytes such as toxic ions. Consequently, successful demonstrations of the proposed sensor technology will facilitate wider market acceptance and penetration of personalized mobile-enabled water quality monitoring devices. Another aspect of the project is to enable ?citizen scientist? to partake in environmental data collection and spread sustainability education.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project proposes to develop a smartphone-based electrical sensor technology for real-time water quality monitoring. Currently, spectrometry, capillary electrophoresis, chemical reduction methods, and gas chromatography coupled mass spectroscopy are some of the most widely used techniques for water quality analysis; however, these instruments are bulky and costly; the methods are time consuming, and involve laborious sample processing steps requiring well-trained personnel in a laboratory setting; In order to meet the market need for a portable, low-cost, and easy-to-use water analysis technology, the project will investigate a smartphone integrated electrical readout sensor platform which will be able to address all of the above issues by: 1) the development of a low-cost, portable sensor package consisting of an electrochemical sensor chip, a driver circuit, and rechargeable battery power for standalone operation; 2) the application of polymer immobilized ion sensing coatings to increase the selectivity during ion detection in a non-laboratory setting; 3) the use of algorithm against calibration curve to automatically detect and quantify toxic ion, and 4) the use of smartphone in-built GPS and mobile broadband function to combine the sensing results with geospatial information and uploaded to the Cloud for further analysis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
National Science Foundation Small Business Innovation Research Phase I (Award # 1519800, “A Smartphone-Based Handheld Sensor for Accurate and Quantitative Detection of Toxic Ion Contaminants in Environmental Water”) support enabled Mobosense LLC to develop a smartphone-based electrical sensor technology for real-time water quality monitoring.

Low-cost, portable, reliable, accurate, easy to use, and real time sensor equipment is important for NGOs, environmentalists and regulators, who need to test and measure nitrate contamination in water to enforce environmental quality and safety. For normal citizens living on well water also have the concern of their water safety. However they have no access to first-handed pollution information without huge analyzing and labor cost. Currently quantitative water quality testing is a long process with water sample collection and then analysis in laboratories. Conventional bench-top water analysis techniques are unsuitable for in-field measurement due to bulky and high cost instruments and laborious sample processing steps. Mobile-based water monitoring technology with comprehensive characterization functions is not readily available yet.

This Phase I SBIR project successfully demonstrated the proof-of-concept of a disposable sensor and its manufacturability. Based on mass manufacturable electrochemical sensing technology, miniaturized potentiostat electronic circuit, and plug-ins, MoboSense platform allows anyone with a smart phone to perform chemical analysis. By placing a single drop of sample on the sensor, the mobile app developed under this project, scan the sample for contaminants such as nitrate. Combined with GPS and mobile broadband, sensing results with geospatial information are uploaded to the Cloud and social network sites such as twitter where more value-added services can be provided. During the Phase I project, we demonstrated the response of the smartphone-integrated sensor using to a range of nitrate concentrations close to EPA limits. Proposed Phase II work will focus on to develop the sensor mass production strategy by driving down the manufacturing cost and sensor power consumption by an order of magnitude while improving the sensor repeatability and accuracy as well as  the software integratability with other existing data portal in the environmental data ecosystem. The technical results gained in the entire NSF SBIR Phase I project will address all technical concerns and fully demonstrate the feasibility of this technology for in-field mobile water monitoring with strong data connectivity and easy dissemination among smartphone users worldwide, which will justify the commercial impact of this technology as well as the investment and effort on better and yet cheaper sensor chip, integrated circuit and software design and prototyping on our commercialization roadmap.

The broader impact/commercial potential of the proposed project is enormous. The developed technology provides a portable, low-cost plug and play sensor product catering to the needs of water quality monitoring market, a global market with a compounded annual growth rate of 4-6%. Mobosense sensor technology bridge the gap between the low-end, low-cost qualitative sensor (such as nitrate strip) and high-end, high cost quantitative sensor (such as mass spectrometer) by providing low-cost, sensitive, accurate tools for quantitative measurement of nitrate in water sample. In general, the developed sensor technology will facilitate wider market acceptance and penetration of personalized water quality monitoring devices. The smartphone-integrated sensor also enable “citizen scientist” to partake in environmental data collection and spread sustainability education.
